{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3652505,"name":"6894 Lead prog/driver","username":"Mochatitan","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mochatitan/{size}/237112_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-13T15:55:52.402Z","cooked":"

My VH-109 radio was not using wifi after competition, so we went through the process of reconfiguring it to the old settings, but then it still didnâ€™t do wifi.
We tried installing new firmware and reconfiguring, still nothing.
I tried switching to a different brand new VH-109, configured and nothing. Reinstall firmware and configure, still nothing.
The robot still runs when you plug Ethernet into the DS port, but it wonâ€™t let you connect to it via wifi. Please Iâ€™m desperate.

NathanZhou:

dip switch?

To clarify, in case OP isnâ€™t awareâ€¦ the VH-109 has three switches on the back, one of which enables the 2.4GHz WiFi. This is generally recommended (I think) to be turned off at competitions, but can be useful to turn on when running the robot at home. If you donâ€™t have a 2.4GHz light showing up on the front of the radio, this is VERY likely the reason why.

Please note that the other two switches toggle the Passive PoE functionality on the radio, and if you turn this feature on while an incompatible device is connected, you can fry the device, so make sure youâ€™re getting the right switch!

DIP Switch Reference: https://frc-radio.vivid-hosting.net/overview/wiring-your-radio#power-over-ethernet-poe-for-downstream-devices
Status light Reference: https://frc-radio.vivid-hosting.net/overview/led-status-indications

To add additional context, since you mentioned having 2 VH-109, you may want to set them up to run on 6GHz to ensure more consistent wireless connection.

You can find documentation on that here
